newsitem.title: USA: NASD says muni whistleblower's charges meritless.
newsitem.headline: NASD says muni whistleblower's charges meritless.

text.p: NASD said Thursday that charges by one of its former investigators that she was forced to resign because of her aggressive probe of "pay-to-play" in the municipal bond market are "meritless."
"The National Association of Securities Dealers believes that Ms. Carr's claims are meritless and will vigorously defend the lawsuit," an NASD spokesman said in an interview.

Theresa Carr was a senior compliance examiner in NASD's district 10 office in New York City until June 19, when, according to a complaint she filed in New York Supreme Court Wednesday, she was essentially forced to resign.

Carr is seeking $20 million in retribution from NASD for "maliciously" discharging her, breach of contract, "tortious interference" with her probe of muni deals, sexual harassment, and sexual discrimination, the complaint states.
NASD's spokesman said the group is "disappointed and surprised" by Carr's action. Carr resigned "of her own accord" in spring 1996, and six weeks ago asked NASD to hire he back, the spokesman said.
He said Carr's lawyer unsuccessfully sought a settlement with NASD. "Her counsel sought a payment from NASD to keep the suit from being filed. NASD declined," he said.
"I asked them if they wanted to settle and do the right thing," Carr lawyer Jacob Zamansky, a partner with Singer Zamansky in New York City, said in a telephone interview.
"They've ruined this woman's career," he charged. "Carr is a whistleblower. She's blowing the whistle on NASD's cozy relationship with major financial securities firms."

Zamansky said Carr was forced to resign for uncovering muni market violations of Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board's rule G-37, which restricts political contributions by bond firms to state and local elected officials with whom they do business.
Securities and Exchange Commission recently issued a tough report criticizing the NASD for inadequate oversight of the municipal securities market.

Zamansky, meanwhile, said he expects the NASD to file a motion seeking confidentiality of key court documents in the case. "I'm not going to agree to any confidentiality whatsoever," he told Reuters. "I'll go to the court of appeals on that," he said.
"We are going to lift the lid off the NASD," he said.
